summary: This document is an email chain from November 14, 2019, within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, discussing press coverage of the Jeffrey Epstein estate's proposal to establish a victims' compensation fund. It includes forwarded news articles detailing the fund proposal, resistance from some accusers' lawyers, and the filing of new civil lawsuits against the estate by three accusers represented by the Boies Schiller firm.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Retained by Jeffrey Epstein's estate to set up a claims resolution program to pay accusers.

persons.name: Camille Biros
persons.context: Tapped to help set up the Epstein victims' compensation program; an architect of programs for Catholic Church abuse scandal victims.

persons.name: Jordana Feldman
persons.context: Tapped to help set up and then carry out the Epstein victims' compensation program; played a critical role in the September 11 Victims Compensation Fund.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Filed a court document stating his client does not believe alternative dispute resolution should stay the course of litigation against the estate.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Objected to the compensation plan being put together without consulting accusers and their lawyers, calling it 'a continuation of his crimes and abuse after his death.'

persons.name: David Brodie
persons.context: Said he was 'cautiously optimistic' about the possible resolution program but had many questions about how claims would be handled.

persons.name: Bennet Moskowitz
persons.context: Hired by the estate to handle lawsuits by the accusers; did not respond to requests for comment on the proposed program.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, Epstein's longtime lawyer
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's estate; was Epstein's longtime lawyer in New York; did not respond to a request for comment.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, accountant for Epstein's companies
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's estate; was an accountant for some of Epstein's companies; did not respond to a request for comment.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Represented three new accusers suing the estate; called a settlement program 'a positive step'; his firm previously represented an accuser in a defamation suit against Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Joshua Schiller
persons.context: Represented the Farmer sisters in litigation against the Epstein estate.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Represented the Farmer sisters in litigation against the Epstein estate.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned as visiting Epstein's mansion; has been in a feud with Boies Schiller firm over defamation claims; forcefully denies allegations of sexual misconduct.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused of procuring young women and underage girls for Epstein; alleged to have participated in abuse; mentioned in new lawsuits.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure whose estate is the subject of the compensation fund proposal and civil lawsuits; died by suicide in August 2019 while facing federal charges.

persons.name: Matthew Goldstein
persons.context: Author of the New York Times article about the possible victims fund.

persons.name: Tom McParland
persons.context: Author of the article 'Boies Schiller Sues Jeffrey Epstein Estate on Behalf of 3 Sexual Abuse Accusers.'

events.title: Three New Lawsuits Filed Against Epstein Estate
events.description: Three new lawsuits were filed in Manhattan federal court by Epstein's accusers, including two sisters, represented by David Boies's firm.

events.title: NYT Reports on Possible Epstein Victims Fund
events.description: The New York Times reported on a court filing disclosing that Epstein's estate was considering a 'claims resolution program' to pay accusers, to be set up by Kenneth Feinberg.

events.title: Federal Indictment Against Epstein Dismissed
events.description: Federal prosecutors dismissed the sex-trafficking indictment against Jeffrey Epstein after his suicide, starting the clock for crime victims to file civil lawsuits.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution from a minor; court filings estimated he had sexual activity with at least 30 underage girls.

events.title: Epstein's Death by Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein killed himself in August 2019 while facing federal sex trafficking charges at the Manhattan Correctional Center.

locations: Southern District of New York (federal court)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's estate, valued at about $577 million, proposed a 'claims resolution program' to pay accusers, to be administered by Kenneth Feinberg and his team.
Some accusers' lawyers, like Roberta Kaplan and Bradley Edwards, objected to the compensation plan, arguing it was being developed without victim input and could exacerbate victimization.

Three new civil lawsuits were filed against the Epstein estate on November 12, 2019, by accusers represented by David Boies's firm, alleging abuse by Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell between 1995 and 2002.
The document notes that federal prosecutors in Manhattan are continuing to investigate whether Epstein's associates and employees were linked to the conspiracy.
A new New York law allows child victims of sexual abuse to file claims for damages many years later, which some of Epstein's accusers are using.
